DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator Coates:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say a few words on the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority Act. I have recently become a member of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I commend the report to the Senate. I believe that it should be considered in some detail because it is part of a general program of looking at late and qualified reports which come to this Parliament. This report concerns the 1983-84 annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority. During the last few years this Authority has not been without controversy. The excuses given for the report being late were that it took the Authority from July to December 1984 to prepare a draft report and that the Department of Territories required a decision from the Minister to be made on the transfer of moneys to the Australian Capital Territory Totalizator Agency Board operations revenue accounts. Apparently this operation took until May 1985. The interesting point about this is that the Department claimed that the Christmas break and the absence on leave of key departmental officers during December 1984 and January 1985 were the main reasons for this delay. That does not explain the months of February, March and April and there does not appear to be any satisfactory explanation for the extra three months which do not fit in with the excuse that was given.

SPEECH.PARA: Qualification of the financial statements were based on the fact that ACT-TAB funds were invested in accepted bills of exchange and that this was in contravention of the provisions of the Betting (Totalizator Agency) Ordinance 1975. The funds that were credited to the poker machine trust account were invested when no power to carry out such investment was available under the Poker Machine Control Ordinance. It was claimed by the legal section of the Department of Territories that because things were not expressly forbidden they could be done and this is detailed on page 11 of the report. This is a very interesting excuse and it seems to be typical of the attitude that prevails when there is little or no oversight of a given department. Advice should have been sought from the Attorney-General's Department. Page 12 of the report indicates that both the Auditor-General's Office and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations strongly support that view. We look forward to improvements. I understand that the 1985-86 report is on time.

A couple of incidental matters happened during this year. Last year the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority supported an applicant for a public broadcasting station, 2SSS FM-and the station is now on air with sporting and music format. There was quite a bit of controversy in the Senate over this station. At that stage the Authority seemed to take a gambling attitude towards the funds in its care and its responsibilities. However, this is not dealt with in the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not an issue under examination.

—It was not an issue that was canvassed at all but I believe that the Authority has entered into various proposals. I also note that in Estimates committee hearings the Gaming and Liquor Authority told us that the bulk of wine sales in the Australian Capital Territory is at the lower end of the price scale and that the Authority does not expect dollar sales figures to decline as a result of the increased sales tax. The Authority was not asked any questions concerning the contents of this report in the Estimates committees. I commend the Committee for its work in this area. I understand that the Committee will be looking very closely at reports which transgress the various timing rules for presentation and which are qualified by the Auditor-General. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Examination of Annual Reports

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator Colston:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week when I spoke to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts I foreshadowed that, after consultations with colleagues, today I would move an amendment to the motion that is before us that the Senate take note of this report. Accordingly, I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add, `and

(a) agrees with the Committee's conclusion that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's approach to the Committee's inquiry was incorrect and that the ABC and any summoned officers of the ABC should have answered the Committee's questions;

(b) asserts that the ABC and any other witnesses before Senate committees have an obligation to co-operate and to answer questions within the terms of reference of Senate standing committees and Senate Estimates committees alike; and

(c) requests the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts to consider, in the light of its own evidence and the answers subsequently given by the ABC to Senate Estimates committees, whether further investigation is required.'

In speaking briefly to the amendment, I bring to the attention of the Senate that last week in my presentation to the debate on this report I outlined the difficulty that had arisen out of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's failure to be accountable to parliament. I reiterated the principle we all support, that is, that the ABC and statutory authorities set up under legislation from this Parliament and receiving public money by decision of this Parliament should not only be accountable but also be seen to be accountable to parliament. Three matters that summarise the ABC's position can be referred to briefly. In its written submission to the Committee's inquiry the ABC set out its approach in the following sentence:

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 guarantees the editorial independence of the Corporation's program services. The ABC holds its power to make programming decisions as a trust on behalf of the people of Australia, for which it is accountable to Parliament, but in which by law and convention neither the Government nor Parliament seeks to intervene.

I reject that statement; I think it is untenable because the ABC is saying: We want to be accountable in theory but not in practice. The claim is made that such accountability cannot be required by either law or convention. Neither is true. Certainly the Senate Committee does not hold to the ABC's view and a remedy to the impasse with which the ABC presented the Committee needs to be found. It is my contention and the contention of many honourable senators whom I have consulted along with the Chairman of the Committee that the amendment that is before us puts this matter into a clear light and provides a clear solution.

I note that the Committee found that the ABC thought that it could pick and choose which parliamentary committee it would be accountable to. The ABC tried to say to us: `We are quite ready to give answers to an Estimates committee of the Senate but we will not give answers to a standing committee of the Senate'. The amendment that is before us clearly asserts the view of all of us in the Senate that witnesses from statutory authorities who appear before the Senate committees-and, indeed, the ABC witnesses in this context-cannot make any distinction and cannot pick and choose but must be answerable to and must co-operate in a similar way with Senate committees of all kinds.

The ABC, in the statement I have quoted from its submission, tried to maintain its case for protection from accountability on the grounds of an assertion that Parliament could not inquire into the safe area of programming decisions. I agree that the Parliament, and I trust the Government, should not intrude into this area. Certainly, the Liberals when in government did not seek to interfere with the programming decisions of the ABC. It would be wrong for politicians to say that the ABC cannot put on an evening news because it offends them or that it cannot put on a Four Corners program because it contains material that is not to their political liking. The principle of not interfering with programming decisions is quite sound. But it is entirely wrong for the ABC, or any other statutory authority, to apply that protection to all of the decisions that it makes. It is quite wrong for it to apply that principle to the grey area between the protected area and the fully accountable area. It is on the question of where that line should be drawn that we very much disagree with the ABC in this case. I believe, and the Senate Committee believes, that the ABC should be fully accountable to the Parliament in terms of the general decisions it makes in respect of services and finance. I believe it is wrong for the ABC to try to evade accountability in respect of its financial and general service decisions on the spurious ground that these in fact amount to program decisions.

The Senate Committee was in no doubt that this was the case and that the impasse that the ABC had presented us with in the conduct of this inquiry could be, and in the view of many ought to be, regarded as contempt of the Senate. In the amendment that is before us I am not seeking to suggest anything with regard to contempt. In my view, any such matters that arise in the future should be referred to the Privileges Committee. In order to clarify this matter, we sought an opinion from the Attorney-General's Department on the legal grounds concerning these issues. The Attorney-General's Department wrote two letters on this matter which are appended to the report. I quote from the Attorney-General's findings:

c . . . the ABC, through its representatives, cannot lawfully refuse to answer questions put to it by the Education and Arts Committee . . . The Committee may refer refusal by a witness to answer questions within the Committee's terms of reference to the Senate and the Senate may treat that refusal as a contempt.
Moreover, the Attorney-General's opinion on the position of the ABC as a statutory authority is as follows:

The thrust of the ABC's submission, as I understand it, is that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 gives the ABC a substantial measure of independence, including independence in relation to programming decisions. If the argument be that, as a consequence of the independence conferred on the ABC by statute, the ABC is as a matter of law beyond the reach of parliamentary scrutiny, then the argument is in my view misconceived. The provisions on which the ABC relies relate to the relationship between the ABC and the executive government. The powers of the Parliament to enquire into a matter, and to require information for that purpose, do not depend upon that matter being within the control of the executive government . . . it is in my view abundantly clear that statutory provisions freeing an authority from day to day ministerial direction in no way put that authority beyond the reach of parliamentary scrutiny, particularly in the context of a parliamentary inquiry into the administration and execution of that authority's constituting legalisation. The Senate has itself expressed a similar view . . .

There is no doubt in the Senate Committee's mind that there should have been accountability in respect of the matters raised with the ABC. To clarify this matter ultimately, I commend the amendment to the Senate and I look to all senators from all parties to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before commenting on the motion and the amendment before the Senate, I remind the Senate that I spoke to the substantive motion on 17 September this year. The record of my remarks commences at page 576 of the daily Hansard. The record of Senator Teague's earlier statements commence at page 2038. I support the amendment moved by Senator Teague. I would like to examine certain aspects of that amendment, which states that the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) agrees with the Committee's conclusion that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's approach to the Committee's inquiry was incorrect . . .
In part, the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, at page 67 of its report to the Senate, stated:
. . . the Committee reports that it considers the ABC's approach to the Committee's inquiry was incorrect . . .

What exactly was the approach of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation? Basically the ABC refused to co-operate with the Senate Committee. It refused to answer questions and, if I may be permitted to say so, it treated the Committee with the utmost contempt. For example, after refusing to supply certain factual information to the Committee at a public hearing in Brisbane, the ABC a few days later took out a half-page advertisement in the Courier-Mail, outlining the information which the Committee had requested. In addition, it readily supplied a Senate Estimates committee with information it had refused to supply to the Senate Standing Committee. The amendment then states:
. . . and that the ABC and any summoned officers for the ABC should have answered the Committee's questions;
This is mentioned on page 67 of the report which states, in part:
. . . that the ABC should answer the questions which the Committee asks on behalf of the Senate.

In the report it is noted that, when the Committee summoned witnesses, the witnesses refused to answer the Committee's questions, principally on the grounds that they were before the Committee as private citizens, not as employees of the ABC. The Committee regarded this argument to be quite spurious and the amendment states that those officers should have answered the questions put to them. The amendment moved by Senator Teague then states:

(b) asserts that the ABC and any other witnesses to Senate Committees have an obligation to co-operate and to answer questions within the terms of reference of Senate Standing Committees and Senate Estimates Committees alike;

In this respect I draw the attention of the Senate to pages 99 and 100 of the report. This matter was mentioned just a short time ago by Senator Teague. An opinion from the Attorney-General's Department states quite clearly that the Committee's inquiry was within the terms of reference of the Committee. The final paragraph of the amendment states:

(c) requests the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts to consider in the light of its own evidence and the answers subsequently given by the ABC to Senate Estimates Committees whether further investigation is required.

This part of the amendment refers to information provided at an Estimates committee hearing after the information had been withheld from the Standing Committee. If this amendment is passed, as I consider it should be, the Standing Committee will consider the evidence now available and determine whether further investigation is required.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ryan) agreed to:
That General Business Orders of the Day relating to the consideration of Committee reports pursuant to Sessional Order be not further proceeded with this day.
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Ryan) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Mr President, on 25 September 1986 the Prime Minister announced a range of decisions taken by the Government to give effect to our commitment to improve the efficiency of the public sector.

This Bill implements those decisions that require amendment of legislation-in particular amendment of the Public Service Act and repeal of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act.

Mr President, from the beginning of this Government's term in office we recognised that there were substantial barriers to productivity and efficiency in many industries because of inefficient work and management practices. Those barriers had built up and become ingrained over many years and would not be changed overnight.

We recognised that change was vital if we were to maximise our economic potential. Consequently, agreements to address such practices formed an integral part of proposals to restructure the steel industry, the heavy engineering industry, the motor vehicle industry, the shipbuilding industry, and most recently the ship repair industry.

The need to address inefficient work and management practices was agreed by both business and union representatives at the work practices meeting convened by the Federal Government. This meeting was a major initiative and the resultant agreement was a vital step forward in tripartite co-operation to address inefficient practices and improve productivity.

The Government is therefore giving a lead to changing work practices in the private sector. It is however, equally determined that its own house should be in order. This Bill is part of that process. Taken together with this Government's Public Service reform legislation passed in 1984, this amounts to the most substantial amendment of Public Service employment legislation since the introduction of the present Act in 1922.
The most significant areas of change in the current legislation are-
revised redeployment and retirement provisions in circumstances of excess officers, inefficiency invalidity and loss of essential qualifications, and
changes to the promotion and the promotion appeals system.
In addition many other amendments are made consistent with the Government's desire to simplify and streamline a range of personnel processes.
There is a common thread to these changes-increased efficiency and better management. The Government expects its managers to manage. It is establishing the framework within which that can take place.
Turning first to the tenure of public servants.
This Bill repeals the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979.
As the Prime Minister said in his statement, this Act has not provided a satisfactory basis for the redeployment and retirement of staff.
In its place, this Bill inserts new provisions in the Public Service Act which provide for circumstances of excess staff, inefficiency, invalidity or loss of essential qualifications.
Surplus Staff

The Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act has not provided an efficient or satisfactory mechanism for dealing with surplus staff. The processes of the Act are extremely complex; it does not provide for an effective voluntary retrenchment scheme; it provides too many stages of appeal; and its potential for providing a Commonwealth employment-wide redeployment system has not been realised. Further its processes are extremely time consuming and it can take up to two years to finalise a surplus staff situation under the CE (RR) Act Award.

The Government has decided to simplify and speed up the processes of dealing with surplus staff. Detailed procedures have been kept out of the new Public Service Act. Negotiations will take place with the unions to obtain a new redeployment and retirement award to apply to all public servants to provide common consultation, notice and benefit provisions.

When a potential redundancy arises the Secretary of a Department will notify the relevant unions and the Board. After consultation with the unions, where redeployment prospects are poor, and where the Board approves, staff will be eligible for lump sum termination benefits if they agree to voluntary retrenchment. Voluntary retrenchment, where necessary will be able to be offered one month after the unions have been provided with the relevant facts. A voluntary retrenchment payment of 2 weeks' for each year of service with a minimum of 4 weeks' and a maximum of 48 weeks' pay, plus 4 weeks notice of payment in lieu is proposed. Staff will be given one month to elect to take retrenchment.

Using this approach, where redundancies are unavoidable, the aim will be to have voluntary retirements achieved within 2 months. Secretaries and the Public Service Board will continue to accept an obligation to take reasonable action to find alternative suitable employment in the Service, before exercising the power to involuntarily retrench or reduce an officer's classification. In these circumstances, the current income maintenance periods of 6 or 12 months will be retained, beginning from the date of the offer of voluntary retrenchment, that is at least 2 months earlier than the current processes.

As an essential protection against arbitrary or capricious action by management there will be in the Public Service Act a right of appeal against involuntary retrenchment or reduction in classification to a tri-partite Redeployment and Retirement Appeal Committee established by the Merit Protection and Review Agency.
Inefficient Staff

The repeal of the Redeployment and Retirement Act and the substitution of new streamlined provisions in the Public Service Act will have a substantial effect on management's ability to deal with inefficient staff.
The Government acknowledges that most public servants are conscientious, hard working and efficient. However, there are exceptions, as there must be in any big organisation.
As the Prime Minister said in his Ministerial Statement, the Government expects the power given to Departmental Secretaries in respect of non-performing staff to be used in appropriate circumstances.

Poor performers will be given a formal warning in writing and a 3 month period in which to reach the necessary standard. If they do not improve, the Secretary on the advice of an Assessment Committee will be able to reduce them to a lower level or to retire them.

The officer will have one month's notice of redeployment to a lower level or retirement and a right to appeal to a Redeployment and Retirement Appeal Committee established by the Merit Protection and Review Agency. The new measures are markedly different from those under the previous arrangements which provided for a multiplicity of appeals and a requirement for the Public Service Board to attempt to redeploy inefficient staff. The new provisions will be a significant spur to efficient performance.
Promotions and Appeals
Mr President, I turn now to the promotion and promotions appeals system.
The Government is firmly committed to promotion solely on the basis of merit. The Public Service is justifiably proud of the absence of cronyism from its ranks.
There is no place for patronage, favouritism or discrimination.

This Bill strengthens and extends the existing prohibitions on patronage, favouritism and discrimination. Section 33 of the Act will state categorically that powers are to be exercised without patronage, favouritism or discrimination. The disciplinary provisions will be amended to make express reference to the fact that patronage, favouritism or discrimination amount to misconduct and render officers liable to disciplinary action.

The Bill amends the definition of efficiency for promotion decisions. It will be broadened to permit Secretaries of Departments to consider the potential for future career development of applicants and their capability to perform a variety of jobs at the same level as well as their suitability for the particular vacancy. This will lead to more realistic selection decisions and more flexible staffing.

Whilst the present promotion and appeal system is generally providing good results, it is far too expensive and time consuming. When an appeal is involved it is estimated that, on average, it takes 36 weeks to fill a vacancy.

Measures must be taken to reduce the costs and time involved when making promotions. This Bill and associated regulations will exclude appeals against promotions to positions above Clerical Administrative Class 8 and equivalent grades in other occupations.

These positions are managerial, senior technical and professional in nature. This is already recognised by the cut-off of eligibility for over-time payments above this level. In such cases it is not appropriate for an external body such as the Promotion Appeal Committee to be substituting its view for that of departmental management as to who is best suited to do the job.

However, as a protection against improper selection practices, the Merit Protection and Review Agency will be able to recommend to the Departmental Secretary that a promotion be cancelled if an unsuccessful applicant can establish, to its satisfaction, that the promotion decision was affected by patronage, favouritism or discrimination or that there was a serious defect in the selection process, and that it is unreasonable for the promotion to stand.
Other significant changes to the promotion appeal system include the reduction of the appeal period and the limitation of the right to appeal to original applicants.

The Government sees the increased use of Joint Selection Committees as making a significant contribution to reducing the costs of selection processes, particularly where bulk promotions are concerned.
The legislation will be amended to introduce a special category of management-initiated Joint Selection Committees.
After consultation with the unions, the Board will notify in the Gazette the circumstances in which these Committees may be used.

The Committees will comprise a Convenor nominated by the Merit Protection and Review Agency, a nominee of the Department and, if nominated within a prescribed period, a nominee of the relevant union. If no union nomination is forthcoming the Committee will nevertheless be able to proceed. However, due to the consultation with the unions it is expected that there will be full co-operation during the trial period of 12 months. Where the Secretary accepts the unanimous advice of a Joint Selection Committee, the promotion will not be subject to appeal.

The Government would expect these procedures to be used in bulk selection situations in agreed areas such as the Tax Office, the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Department of Social Security where significant numbers of vacancies at the same level are to be filled simultaneously.

It is expected that, together with revised guidelines on selections, these changes to the promotion and appeal systems will significantly reduce the time taken to fill positions and the number and cost of appeals. This must lead to a more responsive and efficient Service.
Mr President, I now wish to mention some of the other more important features of the Bill.

The Bill includes a number of changes to the disciplinary provisions. This aims at reducing unnecessary procedural steps, providing more relevant penalties and removing costly appeals against minor disciplinary actions.

There are also a number of amendments designed to permit the devolution of casework from the Public Service Board to Departments. Over the years the Board has progressively delegated many of its functions; this is a continuation of that process. It is fundamental to the aim of providing managers with the power to manage.
A range of other delegations will be implemented by administrative action by the Public Service Board.
As mentioned in the Prime Minister's Statement, many of the Government's decisions will be implemented by subordinate legislation or other administrative action.

Regulations are currently being drafted to simplify selection procedures for temporary higher duties by allowing departments to select the most suitable officer available, having regard to operational requirements and abolishing appeals against such selections, unless the period of acting extends beyond 3 months. These regulations are not dependent upon legislation and it is expected that they will be made as soon as possible.
Arrangements are already in hand to begin the review by the Public Service Board of flextime.

Honourable senators will also recall the Prime Minister's announcement of the establishment of an efficiency scrutiny unit to be headed by Mr David Block, AO and the announcement of a number of other measures to enhance financial efficiency.
The efficiency scrutiny unit is expected to be up and running early in the new year and early action is being taken to implement the decisions announced on financial management.
Financial Impact

It is not possible precisely to quantify the financial savings that will flow from the passage and implementation of this Bill. Major savings will be derived from more efficient personnel practices generally.

In particular there will be savings from a more streamlined promotion and appeal system, the removal of appeals above Class 9 and the increased use of Joint Selection Committees. More efficient processes for handling surplus staff situations and the significant changes relating to the retirement of inefficient staff will also be a source of significant long-term savings for the Government.

Mr President, this Government has done more than any of its predecessors to reform the Public Service to maximise its efficiency and effectiveness and to improve the quality of services provided to the Government and the community.
This Bill makes further significant changes towards that same end.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the annual report of the Australian Audit Office for 1985-86.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Adequacy of Quarantine in Torres Strait Area

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, I present a report on the adequacy of quarantine in the Torres Strait area, dated October 1986, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report concerns the adequacy of quarantine in the Torres Strait area and, in particular, the risk of the entry to Australia of exotic animal and plant diseases via the Torres Strait. As a result of its inquiry, which included a visit to Cape York Peninsula and a number of Torres Strait islands, and a hearing on Thursday Island, the Committee has made a number of recommendations which I hope honourable senators will study and discuss at a later date.

I thank the members of the Committee for their co-operation, and the staff of the secretariat, particularly Peter Roberts and Mary Louise Willheim, for their untiring assistance. I also thank the leaders and members of the Aboriginal and Islander communities who made our visit to the Straits pleasurable as well as informative. I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
On behalf of the Members of the Standing Committee on National Resources, it gives me pleasure to table the Committee's report on the adequacy of quarantine in the Torres Strait area.

The Committee's interest in quarantine goes back to 1978, when it undertook an inquiry on the adequacy of quarantine and other control measures to protect Australia's pastoral industries from the introduction and spread of exotic livestock and plant diseases. During that inquiry, the Committee became aware of the possible introduction of exotic diseases from Indonesia and Papua New Guinea into mainland Australia, and made recommendations for the strengthening of quarantine in the Torres Strait.
The Committee maintained an interest in quarantine in the area and it noted the Government's response to the report in 1980.

In 1985 the Committee received representations from Mr K. Potter and Mr W. Toomer relating to claims of deficiencies in the quarantine system, and the circumstances relating to Mr Toomer's retirement from the Commonwealth Public Service on medical grounds.

The Committee gave serious consideration to these representations and wrote to the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, requesting that consideration to a re-examination of the issues relating to Mr Toomer's retirement be given. In his reply Senator Walsh stated that he had re-examined the issues involved and had reached the conclusion that no worthwhile purpose would be achieved in any such examination. The Committee believes it has no further role in this matter.

The Committee sought a briefing from the Department of Primary Industry to clarify the quarantine situation, and decided that, although a number of its recommendations had been implemented, and the Committee's concerns were generally being met, the Torres Strait remained a high risk area and an inquiry which would look at the issues in more detail was clearly warranted. In May 1985 the Senate agreed to refer the matter to the Committee.

Early in the inquiry the Committee visited Cape York Peninsula and the Torres Strait Islands. Stops were made at Weipa, the former Heathlands cattle station (north east of Weipa), Bamaga at the tip of Cape York Peninsula, Badu, Saibai, Yorke, Horn and Thursday Islands.

The Committee met with local Aboriginal and Islander groups explaining the purpose of its visit at each place and inviting comments and questions relating to quarantine. The Committee was impressed overall by the co-operation and courtesy of the Islander and Aboriginal communities, with their appreciation of their responsibilities in relation to quarantine requirements and their willingness to undertake these responsibilities. The Committee found agreement within the Island communities that quarantine training programs should be set up for Islanders and recommends accordingly.

While it is difficult to associate these little known, idyllic islands with the spread of exotic disease, it is surprising, given the proximity of Papua New Guinea and Irian Jaya to the Islands, that more exotic animal and plant diseases have not already reached mainland Australia via the Strait. Saibai Island, for example, is approximately 4 kilometres from Papua New Guinea and animals can cross at low tide. Papua New Guineans frequently visit Island communities and have a long history of trading and ceremonial associations with the Islanders. Traditional movement of people in the area has occurred from early times. Ceremonies and celebrations in both countries are attended by both Islanders and Papua New Guineans. They involve the use of traditional dress, including feather head dress, beads made from seeds and other items which could pose a quarantine threat. Pigs and fruit consumed at these ceremonies could also pose a serious quarantine threat. The use of outboard motor boats has increased mobility and the quarantine risk has grown accordingly.

Ships from Asia use the waters of the Torres Strait as a major international shipping lane, and refuse from these vessels, and animals and plants carried on board, could also constitute a grave quarantine risk. Conditions in the area are ideal for the introduction of potential virus sources.

A recent factor affecting the operation of quarantine in the area is the Torres Strait Treaty ratified in 1985. The Treaty establishes a Protected Zone for the preservation of the traditional way of life of Islanders and Papua New Guineans. Amongst other things the Protected Zone enables considerable freedom of movement between the Islands and Papua New Guinea. Customs, immigration, quarantine and health procedures are to be applied in a way that will not hinder the movement of traditional inhabitants or performance of traditional activities. Special quarantine arrangements have been made, including two new quarantine zones and some exemptions from normal quarantine of items for use in traditional ceremonies.

The Committee initially held some concerns about these new measures. While the new quarantine zones delineated the area more precisely for quarantine control, the boundaries of these zones need to be understood and respected by traditional inhabitants and visitors. The exemptions of specific items for use in traditional ceremonies could create a quarantine risk.

Quarantine awareness programs for Islanders have been organised, for example a regular radio program and bilingual leaflets, and in time new initiatives will be undertaken to inform visitors of quarantine areas in the Strait.

In the final analysis, the Committee concludes that the effects of the Treaty cannot be assessed for some time and recommends that a review of the quarantine provisions of the Treaty should be undertaken in four years. In the meantime it advocates an assessment of staff resources, so that any increased work load can be offset. The Committee also proposes the exemptions relating to traditional items should be kept under review, and items removed if they pose an unacceptable risk.
The Committee gave serious consideration to the infestation risk in Australia of animal diseases, in particular Screw-worm fly and Newcastle disease.

Screw-worm fly is established in the Papuan swamplands adjacent to the Torres Strait and can infest all warm blooded animals including humans. It is a major threat to Australia's cattle and sheep industry.

Programs have been implemented for the detection of the fly, and the prevention of its southward progression, should it become established on the mainland. The Queensland government proposes to establish a Livestock Free Zone at the northern tip of Cape York Peninsula, intended to control movement of stock and feral animals further south. In addition, a contingency plan involving the production of sterile screw-worm flies in Papua New Guinea should eliminate the fly in the event of an outbreak. The Committee believes these programs are sound and that they should continue. To ensure the continued viability of these programs however, the Committee takes the view that the detection (or monitoring) program and the sterile Screw-worm fly production program should be assessed.

Newcastle Disease can affect domestic poultry and free flying birds and poses a serious threat to the poultry industry in Papua New Guinea and Australia. It is endemic in most major centres in Irian Jaya and there is considerable fear that Newcastle Disease will spread to PNG. If that occurs the threat to Australia would be particularly serious.

A number of responses have been made to the possible introduction of the disease. These include scientific studies, establishment of flocks of birds at Bamaga which would exhibit symptoms of the disease very quickly, prohibition of movement of poultry, production of vaccine, and regulations for the importation of avian material. Papua New Guinea has also taken preventive and monitoring measures. The Committee considered these programs appropriate and endorsed their continuation.

Exotic plant and pest diseases from Papua New Guinea and Irian Jaya have been detected in the area. For example, Citrus canker on Thursday Island and Black Sigatoka, a banana disease, discovered on Murray, Badu, Moa, Thursday Islands and Bamaga in 1981 and on Horn Island in 1984.

Citrus Canker is probably the most serious threat to the citrus industry. It was discovered on Thursday Island in 1984, an eradication program was undertaken and the disease has not recurred. Quarantine measures are in force to prevent citrus plants from entering mainland Australia.

Similar success has not been achieved with Black Sigatoka. The infected plants were destroyed, but the disease broke out again in Bamaga in 1984. The unsuccessful eradication program was abandoned and quarantine restrictions have been imposed. Banana plants cannot be brought from the Islands into Australia or moved south from the Bamaga area.
The reason for the failure of the Black Sigatoka eradication program has not been determined and the Committee recommends that plant quarantine measures in the Torres Strait should be reviewed.
There were a number of other areas of specific concern to the Committee.

The Committee received evidence that live deer are being taken from Prince of Wales Island to mainland Australia, without quarantine checks. These deer could be infested with Screw-worm fly. The Committee recommends an extension of quarantine to that island.

Quarantine legislation has not kept pace with the creation of the Protected Zone and quarantine officers have no power to search vessels coming out of that area. The Committee regarded this as a serious shortcoming and advocated amendment of the Quarantine Act accordingly.

Co-operation is a vital element of quarantine efficiency. In this regard co-operation between Australia, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia is of great importance. The Committee understands that the Tripartite Committee on Animal Health and Quarantine has not met since 1982, and that, as a result, studies of certain diseases, including Screw-worm fly, have not been undertaken. The Committee regrets this situation and proposes that Australia take the initiative and suggest a meeting should be held as soon as possible.

The Committee considers the movement of refugees across the Irian Jayan border into PNG of concern to quarantine. Many exotic diseases are endemic in Irian Jaya, in particular Newcastle Disease. Given the village lifestyle of people in the area, with dependence on pigs, fowls and other animals and the ease with which residents of each country can cross the border, there is grave risk of the spread of animal and plant disease. The Committee sees a need for the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to liaise closely with quarantine officers on the situation.

A quarantine system is only as effective as its enforcement and the Committee is concerned to ensure an acceptable level of human and financial resources is maintained. In this regard the Committee sees a need not only for adequate staff but also for adequate mobility and the Committee has made appropriate recommendations.

In conclusion I wish to thank the members of the Committee for their assistance and co-operation. I thank all the individuals and organisations who made submissions, or assisted the Committee in any other way. Special thanks are due to the Islander and Aboriginal Communities for their hospitality and co-operation during the Committee's visit to the Strait and Cape York Peninsula. I thank George Mye, Chairman of the Island Co-ordinating Council, who travelled with and assisted the Committee. I also thank officers from the Queensland Department of Primary Industries, and Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry who travelled with the Committee and were of great assistance. Finally I would like to thank the staff who worked on this inquiry, particularly Peter Roberts (former secretary), Mary-Louise Willheim (acting secretary), Elizabeth Mountain (research officer) and June Fallick (former steno-secretary).
I commend the report to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Proposals for Variations of Plan of Canberra

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on the Australian Capital Territory I present a report on the proposals for variations of the plan of layout of the city of Canberra and its environs, 88th series, together with minutes of proceedings. I seek leave to make a statement on the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report I have tabled deals with 14 items to vary the city plan, and the Committee recommends approval of all but one of these variations. In its consideration of items in this series the Committee took evidence from 10 witnesses appearing as individuals and representing various organisations. The cost involved in the proposal dealt with in this report is approximately $7.5m, with another $45m estimated for completion of all stages of the Eastern Parkway. I wish to comment on just two of these variations.

SPEECH.PARA: Variation four provides for the deletion of part of the road reservation in Kaye Place, Yarralumla, to allow the area to be included in the lease for the Hotel Canberra and the construction of a rear entrance for the hotel. This forms part of the construction program for the hotel, which should be completed by 1987. An objection to the variation was received from the proprietor of the nearby service station, who claimed that the increased traffic generated by the hotel entrance would jeopardise his business and make access to his service station difficult. I point out that this service station proprietor has for some time had difficulties because of the changes to the roads in the vicinity, including access to Coronation Drive, and also through lack of commitment, I believe, by the National Capital Development Commission and the Department of Territories to resolve the problems thereby created.

At the public hearing, when questioned about his intentions regarding the continued operation of the service station, the proprietor assured the Committee that he would like to carry on as a service station operator. In response to a question regarding the state of negotiations and potential purchase of the service station site by the Hyatt hotel group, the Committee was told that although some discussions had taken place no conclusion had been reached and all negotiations had ceased. Just 11 days after that public hearing the Committee was informed that the service station site had been sold to the hotel group. The Committee is not satisfied that it was made fully aware of all aspects of dealings concerning the future of the service station in Kaye Place. However, as the objection to the variation was then withdrawn, the Committee does not see any reason to withhold approval of the variation.

The one item deferred by the Committee relates to construction of the preliminary stages of the Eastern Parkway, which will provide a parkway access system to Tuggeranong comparable to that existing on the western side of Canberra. The Eastern Parkway will also have benefits in relation to traffic between Queanbeyan and Canberra and for regional traffic travelling between the Monaro Highway and locations to the north. The estimated cost for the construction was $50m at present prices, with that work being carried out in stages over a number of years. While the Committee was provided with some details regarding the shape and construction of the road system, it is not satisfied that it was briefed adequately on the costing component or estimates of traffic flows on particular sections of the road. The Committee has further doubts about the extent to which this road is a priority in the present economic climate, and therefore recommends that this item be deferred pending a full briefing and overview of the proposal at a later date by the National Capital Development Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present a report relating to the construction of a new wharf and seamanship school at HMAS Cerberus, Crib Point, Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-HMAS Cerberus is the Royal Australian Navy's largest training establishment. It occupies a 1,500 hectare site at Crib Point, near Westernport Bay in Victoria. The base has been developed over many years and contains instructional facilities for a number of schools including the seamanship school. The major components of the proposal which the Committee on Public Works examined is the construction of a new building to house the seamanship school, and a wharf including a marina.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee found that existing facilities and arrangements for training sailors in seamanship, survival at sea and ship husbandry are substandard and antiquated. The Committee concluded that the proposed new seamanship school building will meet the Navy's functional requirements.

The report draws attention to two matters which should be further examined by the Department of Defence and the Department of Housing and Construction. The first is the provision of storage space for paints and other flammable products in the ship husbandry section of the building. The Committee believes the location of this storage space should be reviewed and if necessary an alternative location found.

The second is the amount of space available for instructors-65 square metres for 10 instructors. The Committee believes the space allocation provided should be reviewed. Another component of the proposed work is the construction of a wharf for assigned and visiting craft, such as patrol boats, and seamanship training, and a floating marina for training and support craft. The need for these facilities was clearly demonstrated, and the extent and design of the proposed facilities will enable practical seamanship training to be carried out and for operational training and support vessels to be adequately moored and maintained.

Dredging of the turning basin adjacent to the wharf and of the channel into Hann's Inlet is also proposed. The Committee is conscious of the need to ensure that the effects of the dredging on the environment is minimised. On the basis of assurances given by departmental officials, the Committee is satisfied that every precaution will be taken to minimise the effects of the dredging.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present the report relating to the development of HMAS Albatross, Nowra, New South Wales, stage 1.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-HMAS Albatross is located approximately eight kilometres south west of Nowra, New South Wales. The base provides operational maintenance, logistic and administrative support for the aircraft, equipment and personnel of resident squadrons and Royal Australian Navy ships' helicopter flights when disembarked. The base also provides support for Royal Australian Air Force, Army and civilian aircraft operating in the area in support of the fleet or on other tasks.

SPEECH.PARA: A squadron of Seahawk helicopters is to be deployed at the base; the first Seahawk being delivered in March 1988. The proposal is for the provision of facilities to service and maintain the Seahawk helicopters, and for the development of new facilities and the upgrading of existing facilities for the effective and efficient operation of the base. The Committee on Public Accounts concludes that the works proposed will be adequate to support the development of the Seahawks and will also improve the overall efficiency of the base.

Attention is drawn in the report to possible future urban development and whether this may hinder the operations of the base. The Committee concludes that continuing discussions should take place between the Department of Defence and the Shoalhaven City Council to ensure that this will not occur.

Attention is also drawn to the possibility of a future cycleway from Nowra to the base. The Committee believes that there is merit in the Department of Defence having discussions with the Shoalhaven City Council and community groups on this matter.

Finally, the Committee has recommended that consultations should take place with relevant State and local government bodies prior to its consideration of a proposal. The Committee recommends construction of the work in this reference.

That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate on the Australian Institute of Sport legislation on 9 October the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) asserted:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is a policy of our Government, and one we have gone to considerable lengths to implement, that on any Government appointed body there should be as far as possible equal representation of the sexes.

This was when she refused the Australian Democrats amendment to that Bill to achieve such equal representation on the Board of the Australian Institute of Sport. What is the current status on that particular Board? I note that the membership of the Tourism Advisory Council is set out in Additional Estimates material for the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism and there is just one woman among the 21 people listed. I would like to know whether this is a reasonable example of how the Government's policy is being implemented. On the National Australia Day Council there are four women in a list of 14 names. One of the 13 commissioners of the Australian Tourist Commission is female. Does this, in fact, mean that some Ministers have to be worked on a fair bit to be able to get this policy implemented? I seek such an answer from Senator Ryan who is here now.

The other question I would like to follow up relates to the estimates of total expenditure on advertising and promotional activities and general relations by the Government departments during 1985-86. The figure of $49.27m was given without an indication of what it actually included-whether it included on-cost elements and exactly what was meant by this very large figure. Could we get an idea of the on-cost figure which was adopted in this particular case? I would also like to know whether the Minister is able to indicate or to give us an all up advertising and promotional figure for all government operations including statutory bodies. As the co-ordination of advertising occurs within this Department that figure should be available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first series of questions which Senator Vigor posed about the representation of women on various bodies within the portfolios being examined, he answered his own questions to some extent by quoting numbers. I would like to point out to Senator Vigor that the 50 per cent target is a longer term strategy on many boards and commissions throughout the Commonwealth's area of responsibility. There is very close to 50 per cent of women on others. That is still a goal we are pursuing. The way in which we seek suitable people is, first of all, through portfolio advice, but particularly through the register of women which is being compiled by the Office of the Status of Women. In fact, it was started during the time of our predecessors, I must acknowledge. I have frequently invited women such as my parliamentary colleagues Senator Reid and Senator Newman to suggest and to nominate women with a variety of skills and experience in the community who would be suited to appointment. One of the problems that Ministers have is that we still do not have a comprehensive data bank of appropriate women for all kinds of appointments. I repeat my invitation, particularly to Senator Reid and Senator Newman and also, of course, to male senators, that if they are aware of women who have attributes that make them suitable for such appointments to ensure that their curriculum vitaes are forwarded to the Office of the Status of Women to be included on the register of women. That is a common way in which Ministers seek to find suitable women for appointment.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning when we were discussing this matter I raised the question of the Anzac Rifle Range and asked why it was being sold, if the sale must proceed--
—Because we want the money, of course.

—The Minister gave an interesting answer to this question on 23 October. He should apply the same test to himself as he does to others. I asked whether or not the range could be retained, at least so that it would be available for the bicentennial rifle shooting event planned for April 1988, a prestigious international event at which over 16 countries will be represented. As I said previously, 60,000 or more people use the rifle range. A considerable portion of it is a rubbish dump comprising all sorts of things: Asbestos, as I mentioned this morning, building debris, soil, commercial waste, garden debris, tree stumps and car bodies. It has not been compacted. That certainly is significant in terms of the value of the property. The significance of it relates to whether rifle shooting is regarded as a serious sport in this country. We have been told that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has implied to these people that he is attempting to get the decision overturned. Is that correct or is it mere rhetoric to try to keep the sporting groups concerned happy? It is certainly not clear to those involved as to whether any solution is emerging at present.

SPEECH.PARA: The Anzac Rifle Range is the headquarters of the New South Wales Rifle Association, the largest rifle association in Australia. Certainly, the Canberra Rifle Club, which is one of the largest clubs in Australia, has an interest in whether the site is retained. I understand that it is likely that the New South Wales Government will take some interest in this land if it is to be sold as far as zoning is concerned and will require that the foreshore areas be protected and that the tip fill area I have referred to, which is about half the land, should be zoned as open space.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—That is what I am asking the Minister. He is here to answer the questions. I understand that the New South Wales Government is very likely to require this to be the case. If that is the case, the Federal Government should acquaint itself of the fact and know exactly what the status of this land is. The rifle associations will be seeking compensation for the facilities and the money they will lose in planning the bicentennial championship. They will certainly be entitled to recompense for their facilities on the land. I wonder whether any estimate has been made as to how much that compensation will be. In the end, the actual value of the land may well be considerably less than is anticipated. The sale of the Anzac Rifle Range will remove forever from the residents of Sydney their largest shooting complex. It will remove a vital training centre for the defence forces. Over 23,000 service personnel used the range last year.
—Sack them.

—The Minister may say `sack them', but other people have a much higher regard for our defence forces, their need and the role they play in this country. I, for one, want to be certain that our defence personnel have the best possible facilities and opportunities. The sale of the Anzac Rifle Range will remove forever a large open space area from the citizens of Sydney's eastern suburbs. In the event of a serious national emergency, where is there a similar large area on which a number of troops or other personnel could be put for a period? We will get to defence later in these discussions. Tonight it is a matter of trying to find out the true position of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Does he mean what he says in the letters he has written which is that he is actively attempting to seek the Cabinet overturn of this decision, or is that mere rhetoric? What is to happen to the Anzac Rifle Range?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nice to hear Senator Reid talk about somewhere outside the Australian Capital Territory. I think it is a good thing. But on this occasion she has picked an area which I actually know something about. Senator Reid says that the sale of Anzac Rifle Range would deprive the people of the eastern suburbs of Sydney of a large open space. Of course that is true, but it is not an open space they have been able to use. The people of the eastern suburbs of Sydney do not go wandering down the middle of Anzac Rifle Range. They would get shot if they did. What Senator Reid says is nonsense.
—They don't do it twice.
—They certainly do not do it twice. Secondly, certainly part of the area has been a tip. Whole suburbs of houses in Sydney have been built on tips.
—This is uncompacted.

—One can compact it. One can send in things called bulldozers and other things to compact the area. The estimated minimum value of this rifle range is $16m; its maximum value is $40m. The famous Cumberland Oval, the new Parramatta Park, which seats-when Parramatta plays there-something like 30,000 or 40,000 people every Saturday, and even very large numbers when soccer is played there, did not cost anywhere like that amount. The question is: Should the citizens of Sydney-should citizens of Australia-have to pay, in revenue forgone, this amount of money for a rifle range? That is what this matter is about. Of course rifle shooting is a serious sport. Of course the training of people to shoot rifles in the Army is serious, but the Anzac Rifle Range is not the only rifle range in Sydney. It is very far away from the Army depots in New South Wales. To suggest, as Senator Reid does, that civilisation as we know it is going to end because of the sale of this rifle range is fascinating.

SPEECH.PARA: We are given lectures by people such as Senator Reid again and again that we have to cut government expenditure, look to ourselves and make ourselves properly Budget-conscious. Yet she tells us that the Commonwealth should provide land worth anything up to $40m for rifle clubs to enable people to shoot bullets up and down. This is a very good example of the situation we face in this place. We are lectured day after day that we should save money, that we should not waste money and that we should cut down government activities as much as possible. Then Senator Reid comes in here seriously and tells us that we should not sell this rifle range because, apparently, it is important for the defence of the nation and civilisation as we know it.

She makes the other point that in New South Wales the Government might not let us do what we want to do with the rifle range. I have one remark about that. I know that the rifle range is part of Mr Carr's electorate and that he would like to keep a large part of it as open space. He can. There is no reason in the world why he cannot. If he deprives us of $8m or $10m to make it an open area, I am sure that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and others in the Federal Government will ensure that that amount of money is removed from New South Wales's State grants to enable it to indulge itself in that way.

With due respect, Senator Reid cannot come in here and tell us that we have to cut government expenditure and that we have to get rid of unnecessary property, et cetera, and then, as soon as we go to sell a rifle range-a rifle range which is a beautiful place, a lovely, scenic area-tell us that we are depriving the people of the eastern suburbs of Sydney of it when they cannot walk around it or near it for fear of getting shot. She cannot tell us that we cannot use the range because it is a tip area when large areas of Sydney are already built on tip areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has got asbestos in it, too.

—For heaven's sake! The problem with the people of Canberra is that they are frightened of anything that they think is dangerous. Senator Reid should not transfer that to the people of this part of Sydney. They do not believe her. If the rubbish is buried and compacted there is no reason why the area cannot be used as a building area. If the New South Wales Government decides that it cannot, that is its responsibility and cost. The honourable senator should not come in here and tell me, every time we try to make a reduction in government expenditure and get some more revenue, that we cannot do that because of a special interest group that is so far away from the honourable senator's electorate, except for the denizens of the Royal Military College at Duntroon, who I suspect may have written the speech that the honourable senator made tonight. Do we have to put up with that nonsense?

—I have not heard from anyone at Duntroon. I happen to be a patron of the Canberra Rifle Club. Its members have been in contact with me about this matter. There is a vastly different accounting procedure between recurrent expenditure and getting rid of assets. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) dealt with a question about flogging off assets in an answer on 23 October. That is a quite different matter. The second part of what I asked the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), which he did not address, was: If this area is to be sold, can it be retained until the Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships have taken place in April 1988? Can this range be used for that purpose or must those people organising the championships cancel forthwith those events and put the arrangements totally to one side? That is a fairly simple question. I would have thought that it could have been answered easily in the affirmative that, yes, the area can be retained for that event in 1988.
—I doubt that but I will refer the matter to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). There are other rifle ranges in Sydney and this country which could be used.
—They are not as large as this one.
—Of course they are not. No rifle range in this country is as large and on such valuable land as this range.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw attention to the Tourism Advisory Council. It is set up to maintain close consultative links between government and the industry. The terms of the Council state that the membership is designed to reflect in a balanced way the interests of various industry sectors, trade unions and other interested parties. I draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that this Tourism Advisory Council has 18 members and is totally unrepresentative of the industry sectors, trade unions and other interested parties. To begin with, it ignores half of Australia. Of the 18 members, not one comes from Western Australia, South Australia the Northern Territory or Tasmania. All those States, I would have thought, have a keen interest in tourism. As a senator for Tasmania I understand this.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to see that six of the 18 representatives come from the Australian Capital Territory. Four of the 18 come from the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Two of those trade union members are from Queensland and two are from Victoria. If we were to have four trade union representatives on a committee of 18 their State distribution could have been better. When we think about the States that are not represented we think of the International Gateway at Perth, the America's Cup and the great strides that that State has made in tourism in recent years. We think of South Australia and the Northern Territory, the Flinders Ranges and Ayers Rock. We think of Kakadu National Park, about which this Government sometimes thinks a lot and sometimes does not think at all. When we think of Tasmania we think of the South West National Park and Port Arthur, the historic site which once again the Government likes to pick up and put down, depending upon when it is politically advantageous to do so.

Leaving the politics of this aside, I am concerned that out of an advisory council of 18 people, which is designed to reflect in a balanced way the interests of the various industry sectors, we have such an unrepresentative group. I query whether this body is really much use. It meets only twice a year. It does not cost the Commonwealth a huge amount of money but I fear that it is really just an extra body which does not serve much good purpose. We have a tourist Ministers council comprising all the tourist Ministers from the States and the Commonwealth, a national tourism committee of States and industry and the Australian Tourist Commission. I query why we need a Tourism Advisory Council of 18 people who come from a small part of the eastern mainland States-six of them from Canberra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I want to refer to the matters that Senator Reid has mentioned, because I received today a response to a question I asked on 18 September of the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) about the rifle range. In view of the Government's cosmetic decision to pretend that it is doing something reasonable to cut expenses and reduce the deficit by selling this rifle range-which, of course, will be no more than a pimple in terms of the problems it faces-I had specifically asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Has the Government held any discussions with the New South Wales Rifle Association or with the Bicentenary Authority about possible alternate sites for the holding of the planned 1988 Bicentenary Shoot that had been proposed to be held at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar which the Government now proposes to sell.
The extraordinary and uninformative response was:
The Deputy Prime Minister and the Ministers for Defence, Sport, Recreation and Tourism and I-
that is, the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services-

have separately held discussions with representatives of the New South Wales Rifle Association, the Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships and the National Rifle Association about the proposed sale of the Anzac Rifle Range and the impact of such a sale on the planned 1988 Bicentenary shoot.

That is very informative! What was the result of those discussions? Has the Government any proposals to fix up the mess in which it has put this bicentennial arrangement, funded by its left hand-the Australian Bicentennial Authority-if it still speaks to its left hand? In the absence of any coherent response to this question, it is reasonable to ask: What was the outcome of those discussions? Has the Government a coherent plan to fix up this mess? I also asked:

Did the Government in its decision to consider selling the Anzac Rifle Range, take into consideration that the Range is used by about 120,000 people annually, including Defence and Corrective Services personnel.
The response was:
The current usage of the Range by the Commonwealth and various non-Commonwealth users was brought to the Government's attention in its consideration of the proposed sale.

This means that it clearly ignored those considerations, even though the usage rate is enormously high and, as the Minister has conceded, there is no alternative of a similar nature available. I then asked:
What alternative arrangements would be made for these users of the Anzac Rifle Range.
The response was:
Alternative arrangements for current Commonwealth users of the Anzac Rifle Range is a matter for consideration by the relevant Commonwealth departments.

That tells me nothing. That is a classic Yes, Minister nonsense. It is bureaucratic nonsense and claptrap aimed at obfuscation-which is another good bureaucratic word. The real question is: If this is a matter for consideration by the relevant Commonwealth departments, has it been considered? Why can the Senate not be told? Has consideration been given to it and what alternative arrangements will be made? Has the Government an idea, or does it not care? It is adopting its usual arrogant approach when asked to justify some damn fool decision that it has made-which it made before taking into consideration the consequences of what it was doing? In the end, the costs may be far higher.

Why cannot the Government just defer the sale of this range, if it is desperate to sell it, until after the 1988 Bicentenary? I do not know why it cannot and we have not had a coherent response from the Government on that score, except to say that this sale will help the Government's economic objectives in the current financial year. I let the Government know that it will have worse economic problems next year and the year after, if it is still in power-which I doubt. Perhaps it will then need the proceeds far more than it needs them this year in its cosmetic attempts to dress up the extent of the economic disaster it now faces. It has refused to give the Senate any idea of what alternative arrangements are to be made for this bicentennial shoot, which is financed and supported by the Australian Bicentennial Authority-which the Government is now quite prepared to forget. On top of that the Minister said:
I am not aware that the Government has given specific consideration to alternative arrangements for non-Commonwealth users of the Range.
In other words, this is another example of the Senate, the Australian Bicentennial Authority and the rifle shooters being told to go to blazes by an arrogant government.

I turn to another question relating to this Department which concerns the Government Printing Office. Honourable senators have been aware that since printing procedures changed there have been extraordinary delays in the production of the Senate Hansard. We appear to be getting copies a little earlier now than before. We are getting them actually on the morning of the following day-it might be fairly late in the morning. We did have incredible difficulties. From the Senate Estimates committee hearings I note that there seem to have been extraordinary problems. The estimate for overtime for 1985-86 at the Australian Government Publishing Service was $1.55m but the actual overtime expenditure was $2.49m-a very substantial overspending. Written explanations were given about what was going on. The reply stated:

Hansard volumes also increased significantly with Senate Hansard running 34 per cent and House 62 per cent over the previous financial year's volumes. This work has to be produced to tight deadlines, this invariably meant having to utilise extra overtime.

I must say that I was not aware that the House and the Senate were making such massively increased demands on the service. It astounds me that the House has a 62 per cent additional demand for Hansard. I am really staggered. I will not say that I do not believe it but it does seem absolutely extraordinary. The reply also states:
Other factors which contributed to the overall increase in overtime were;
Change in Parliamentary sitting schedules . . .
The reply also lists:
Loss of production and shift continuity when the move from a 40 hour to a 38 hour week occurred.

As the Government is aware, the Opposition has been highly critical of the move towards reduced hours as an additional labour cost at a time when the Australian economy cannot afford it. Here we have a situation in which in one of the Government's own activities this move has created more disruption than the simple cost of reducing from a 40-hour to a 38-hour week would appear to produce. In other words, there is a loss of production and shift continuity. That hidden cost is added to the loss of production due to repetition strain injury. I regret to say that the AGPS has what appears to be an excessive volume of RSI complaints. Out of a total of 34 cases involving invalidity retirement there were 13 instances of retirement due to RSI. As I have already noted concerning other departments, other neck-back injuries and stress related problems seem to make up the bulk of people who retired from that organisation. Given that these additional problems occur, it is worth noting that due to employment level restrictions the area is understaffed. The reply states:

. . . due to ASL restriction, the area is understaffed thus leaving certain machines inoperative. This means that jobs can only be produced on a restricted number of machines thus creating backlogs and limiting the official use of resources.

I am all in favour of the Government saving money, but if by saving money it incurs greater expenditure and inefficient production, more overtime and all the other disruptions that have been put up with, it is totally false economy. If the Government has the capacity to examine simple managerial problems such as the ones that have emerged in the Government Publishing Service, where there are clear inefficiencies emerging from deliberate work and financial practices no doubt imposed by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who cost the Australian Broadcasting Corporation $12m by refusing to allow it to forward cover last year, with that kind of negative approach we can expect that sort of problem. The last comment I make is on the question of publicity and promotion. This emerges through the estimates of this Department. It concerns the general question of advertising. In an article last week in the Australian Financial Review it was evident that the expenditure on fringe benefits tax advertising is going to be far higher than the $2m about which we heard. The figure will be much closer to $5m--

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful!

—Exactly. The advertising promotes in clearly political terms, but financed by the taxpayer, the so-called benefits of this tax, which hits so many people in the community, particularly the business area, which is endeavouring to get itself out of trouble and on which future employment depends in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the Australian Financial Review report, the Government will launch stage 2 of its campaign in early December with a blanket television coverage. We have seen the political and disgraceful nature of the Press advertisements so far. They use an almost subliminal advertising form by dropping the word `fair' all the way through them, even though the way in which this tax is being imposed is patently unfair. I presume that all these sneaky devices will be repeated in the 45-second television commercials. The Australian Financial Review says that again the theme fairness will be repeated. The reality is that this kind of advertising is a disgrace. It is politicising the Public Service because the advertisements are not being signed or authorised by the Government or the Minister; they are being signed or authorised by the Department itself. These advertisements come in this case from the Department of the Treasury and they say `the Treasury', not `the Treasurer'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's who pulls the strings. Senator Walsh goes to sleep when the strings are not being pulled.

—Yes, I agree. The reality is that these advertisements have a political content. It could perhaps be justified if a political person signed the advertisements, even though it would be disgraceful that public money was being used. In this case the Department itself is being corrupted. It is exactly the same sort of political corruption of the bureaucracy that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is trying to implement at the moment by insisting on getting his own appointee from outside into the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. I revealed this matter yesterday. It is causing great turmoil and concern within the Commonwealth Bank because it is exactly the same kind of politicising of the administrative processes that has gone on under this Government. This is an absolute disgrace and I hope that when people watch this unprecedented advertising blitzkrieg, which will of course be financed by the taxpayers of Australia, they will recognise that this is totally improper.
